t: Job 24
Why,*p seeing times are not hidden from the Almighty, do they that know him not see his days?
Some*p remove the landmarks; they violently take away flocks, and feed thereof.
They*p drive away the ass of the fatherless, they take the widow's ox for a pledge.
They*p turn the needy out of the way: the poor of the earth hide themselves together.
Behold,*p as wild asses in the desert, go they forth to their work; rising betimes for a prey: the wilderness yieldeth food for them and for their children.
They*p reap every one his corn in the field: and they gather the vintage of the wicked.
They*p cause the naked to lodge without clothing, that they have no covering in the cold.
They*p are wet with the showers of the mountains, and embrace the rock for want of a shelter.
They*p pluck the fatherless from the breast, and take a pledge of the poor.
They*p cause him to go naked without clothing, and they take away the sheaf from the hungry;
Which*p make oil within their walls, and tread their winepresses, and suffer thirst.
Men*p groan from out of the city, and the soul of the wounded crieth out: yet God layeth not folly to them.
They*p are of those that rebel against the light; they know not the ways thereof, nor abide in the paths thereof.
The*p murderer rising with the light killeth the poor and needy, and in the night is as a thief.
The*p eye also of the adulterer waiteth for the twilight, saying, No eye shall see me: and disguiseth his face.
In*p the dark they dig through houses, which they had marked for themselves in the daytime: they know not the light.
For*p the morning is to them even as the shadow of death: if one know them, they are in the terrors of the shadow of death.
He*p is swift as the waters; their portion is cursed in the earth: he beholdeth not the way of the vineyards.
Drought*p and heat consume the snow waters: so doth the grave those which have sinned.
The*p womb shall forget him; the worm shall feed sweetly on him; he shall be no more remembered; and wickedness shall be broken as a tree.
He*p evil entreateth the barren that beareth not: and doeth not good to the widow.
He*p draweth also the mighty with his power: he riseth up, and no man is sure of life.
Though*p it be given him to be in safety, whereon he resteth; yet his eyes are upon their ways.
They*p are exalted for a little while, but are gone and brought low; they are taken out of the way as all other, and cut off as the tops of the ears of corn.
And*p if it be not so now, who will make me a liar, and make my speech nothing worth?
